#Text=Caspar Schwenckfeld
#Text=Kaspar Schwenkfeld

#Text=Caspar ( or Kaspar ) Schwen(c)kfeld von Ossig ( listen ( help · info ) ) ( 1489 or 1490 – 10 December 1561 ) was a German theologian , writer , and preacher who became a Protestant Reformer and spiritualist .
#Text=He was one of the earliest promoters of the Protestant Reformation in Silesia .
#Text=Schwenckfeld came to Reformation principles through Thomas Müntzer and Andreas Karlstadt .
#Text=However , he developed his own principles and fell out with Martin Luther over the eucharistic controversy ( 1524 ) .
#Text=He had his own views on the sacraments - the Heavenly Flesh doctrine - developed in close association with his humanist colleague , Valentin Crautwald ( 1465 – 1545 ) .
#Text=His followers became a new sect ( see Schwenckfelders ) , which was outlawed in Germany , but his ideas influenced Anabaptism , Pietism on mainland Europe , and Puritanism in England .
#Text=Many of his followers were persecuted in Europe and thus forced to either convert or flee .
#Text=Because of this , there are Schwenkfelder Church congregations in countries such as the United States ( which was then a part of the United Kingdom ) .
#Text=Life
#Text=Early life
#Text=Schwenckfeld was born in Ossig near Liegnitz , Silesia now Osiek , near Legnica , Poland , to noble parents in 1489 . [ 1 ]
#Text=From 1505 to 1507 he was a student in Cologne , and in 1507 enrolled at the University of Frankfurt on the Oder .
#Text=Between 1511 and 1523 , Schwenckfeld served the Duchy of Liegnitz as an adviser to Duke Charles I ( 1511 – 1515 ) , Duke George I ( 1515 – 1518 ) , and Duke Frederick II ( 1518 – 1523 ) .
#Text=From Catholic to Magisterial Reformer to Radical Reformer

#Text=In 1518 or 1519 , Schwenckfeld experienced an awakening that he called a " visitation of God . " Luther 's writings had a deep influence on Schwenckfeld , and he embraced the " Lutheran " Reformation and became a student of the Scriptures .
#Text=In 1521 , Schwenckfeld began to preach the gospel , and in 1522 won Duke Friedrich II over to Protestantism .
#Text=He organized a Brotherhood of his converts for the purpose of study and prayer in 1523 .
#Text=In 1525 , he rejected Luther 's idea of Real Presence and came to a spiritual interpretation of the Lord 's Supper , which was subsequently rejected by Luther .
#Text=Schwenckfeld began to teach that the true believer ate the spiritual body of Christ .
#Text=He pushed for reformation wherever he went , but also criticized reformers that he thought went to extremes .
#Text=He emphasized that for one to be a true Christian , one must not change only outwardly but inwardly .
#Text=Because of the communion and other controversies , Schwenckfeld broke with Luther and followed what some describe as a " middle way " .
#Text=Because of his break from Luther and the Magisterial Reformation , scholars typically categorize Schwenckfeld as a member of the Radical Reformation .
#Text=He voluntarily exiled himself from Silesia in 1529 in order to relieve pressure on and embarrassment of his duke .
#Text=He lived in Strassburg from 1529 – 1534 and then in Swabia .
#Text=Teachings

#Text=Some of the teachings of Schwenckfeld included opposition to war , secret societies , and oath-taking , that the government had no right to command one 's conscience , that regeneration is by grace through inner work of the Spirit , that believers feed on Christ spiritually , and that believers must give evidence of regeneration .
#Text=He rejected infant baptism , outward church forms , and " denominations " .
#Text=His views on the Eucharist prompted Luther to publish several sermons on the subject in his 1526 The Sacrament of the Body and Blood of Christ — Against the Fanatics .
#Text=Publications
#Text=In 1540 Martin Luther expelled Caspar Schwenckfeld from Silesia .
#Text=In 1541 , Schwenckfeld published the Great Confession on the Glory of Christ .
#Text=Many considered the writing to be heretical .
#Text=He taught that Christ had two natures , divine and human , but that he became progressively more divine .
#Text=He also published a number of works about interpreting the Scriptures during the 1550s , often responding to the rebuttals of the Lutheran Reformer Matthias Flacius Illyricus . [ 2 ]
#Text=Death
#Text=In 1561 , Schwenckfeld became sick with dysentery , and gradually grew weaker until he died in Ulm on the morning of December 10 , 1561 .
#Text=Because of his enemies , the fact of his death and the place of his burial were kept secret .
#Text=Schwenkfelder Church
#Text=Schwenkfelder Church in Palm , Pennsylvania
#Text=Schwenckfeld did not organize a separate church during his lifetime , but followers seemed to gather around his writings and sermons .
#Text=In 1700 there were about 1,500 of them in Lower Silesia .
#Text=Many fled Silesia under persecution of the Austrian emperor , and some found refuge on the lands of Count Nicolaus Ludwig Zinzendorf and his Herrnhuter Brüdergemeinde .
#Text=These followers became known as Schwenkfelders .
#Text=A group arrived in Philadelphia in 1731 , followed by five more migrations up to 1737 .
#Text=In 1782 , the Society of Schwenkfelders was formed , and in 1909 the Schwenkfelder Church was organized .
#Text=The Schwenkfelder Church has remained small , and currently there are five [ 3 ] churches with about 3,000 members in southeastern Pennsylvania .
#Text=All of these bodies are within a fifty-mile radius of Philadelphia .
#Text=Schwenkfelder Library & Heritage Center
#Text=The Schwenkfelder Library & Heritage Center is a small museum , library and archives in Pennsburg , Pennsylvania .

#Text=It is the only institution dedicated to the preservation and interpretation of the Schwenkfelder story , including Caspar Schwenckfeld , the Radical Reformation , religious toleration , the Schwenkfelders in Europe and America , and the Schwenkfelder Church .
#Text=The Schwenkfelder Library & Heritage Center has exhibits and programs throughout the year .
